results.title: The Owl and the lemming: an eskimo legend (K)
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, ONF | NFB and Co Hoedeman
results.brief_description: The owl and the lemming in this animated film are short-legged, plumply stuffed puppets made of seal skin by Inuit artists. The accompanying song and voices are in Inuktitut, although the legend is narrated in English. It is a story that all audiences, especially children, will enjoy. Moreover, it preserves on film an example of Inuit folklore they may in time disappear.

results.title: The Owl and Fred Jones
results.creator_credit: Ed Cullen, W.M. Larkins Studio, Equitable Life Assurance Society and Denis Gilpin
results.brief_description: An explanation of how we can control our habits and make them serve us. Fred Jones realises his behaviour is a series of habits - some good, some bad. He would like to change some, like over-eating, but never bothered to try. The owl convinces him that if you want to, if you know how, and if you’re willing to work at it, habits can be changed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ed Cullen, W.M. Larkins Studio, Equitable Life Assurance Society and Denis Gilpin

results.title: The Outsider
results.brief_description: Poses the problem of a girl who, through psychological inhibition, feels cut off from normal, friendly social relations with her school-fellows. Briefly shows how she tends to behave as an isolated individual; how other children distrust and resent her. Another girl tries to understand her difficulties, gives her the opportunity of mixing with the group. The film is stated in simple terms, addressed to secondary school level.

results.title: The Outsider
results.creator_credit: Country Education Project and Barry Washington
results.brief_description: Richard McRoberts and Gary Kinnance begin the discussion with a brief survey of Albert Camus’ life and philosophy to set a background for a fuller treatment of the book. Specific passages are used as springboards for the analysis and explication of Camus’ themes. The meaning and place of “The Outsiders” as a piece of existential literature is discussed.
results.description: Richard McRoberts and Gary Kinnance begin the discussion with a brief survey of Albert Camus’ life and philosophy to set a background for a fuller treatment of the book. results.title: The Outlaw
results.brief_description: A highly fictionalized account of the rivalry and tenuous friendship between Billy the Kidd (Jack Beutel), Doc Holliday (Walter Huston), Pat Garrett (Mitchell Thomas) and a half breed girl (Jane Russel in her screen debut). Much controversy surrounded the films release regarding supposedly steamy scenes between Jack Beutel and Jane Russel, and Hughes’ obvious fixation with Russel’s chest.

results.title: The Otto cycle: gasoline engine
results.creator_credit: Visual Aids Committee, American Association of Physic Teachers and Audio Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Graphically presents the six processes in the gasoline engine cycle. The ideal situation with the elimination of disturbing factors is demonstrated and the Otto cycle is traced on a pressure-volume diagram. The concept of thermal efficiency is discussed in this film.

results.title: The Other World
results.creator_credit: Roman Bittman, ONF | NFB and Claudia Overing
results.brief_description: An exploration of the world of plant and animal life in a Canadian stream. Using underwater and microphotography film techniques, the camera follows some of these underwater life cycles and shows the interdependence of insect, fish and mammal life, which in turn are dependent upon the purity of the water.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roman Bittman, ONF | NFB and Claudia Overing

results.title: The Other Thailand
results.creator_credit: Alan Bateman, Geoffrey Barnes and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Journey into Thailand”.
This program, presented by Keith Adam, describes the southern area of Thailand where the majority of the people are Muslim. It explores the industries in the area and the conflicts with the northern Buddhist population.
